an10.115:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should know bad principles and good principles.

an10.115:1.2.eng: And you should know bad results and good results.

an10.115:1.3.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban”ti.
an10.115:1.3.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.”

an10.115:1.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an10.115:1.5.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
an10.115:1.5.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

an10.115:2.1.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:
an10.115:2.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,

an10.115:2.2.pli: “idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
an10.115:2.2.eng: “The Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.

an10.115:2.5.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti.

an10.115:2.6.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā”ti?
an10.115:2.6.eng: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha?”

an10.115:3.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an10.115:3.2.eng: “This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

an10.115:3.3.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
an10.115:3.3.eng: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

an10.115:3.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma.
an10.115:3.4.eng: Let’s go to him, and ask him about this matter.

an10.115:3.5.pli: Yathā no āyasmā ānando byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā”ti.
an10.115:3.5.eng: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

an10.115:4.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
an10.115:4.1.eng: Then those mendicants went to Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

an10.115:4.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an10.115:4.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. They told him what had happened, and said,

an10.115:5.1.pli: “Idaṃ kho no, āvuso ānanda, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

an10.115:6.1.pli: Tesaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

an10.115:6.2.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho—

an10.115:6.5.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

an10.115:7.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

an10.115:7.3.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

an10.115:7.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma.

an10.115:7.5.pli: Yathā no āyasmā ānando byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā’ti.

an10.115:8.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva mūlaṃ atikkamma khandhaṃ sākhāpalāse sāraṃ pariyesitabbaṃ maññeyya;
an10.115:8.1.eng: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.

an10.115:8.2.pli: evaṃsampadamidaṃ āyasmantānaṃ satthari sammukhībhūte taṃ bhagavantaṃ atisitvā amhe etamatthaṃ paṭipucchitabbaṃ maññatha.
an10.115:8.2.eng: Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you bypassed him, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.

an10.115:8.3.pli: So hāvuso, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti passaṃ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato.
an10.115:8.3.eng: For he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

an10.115:8.4.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ tumhe bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha.
an10.115:8.4.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.

an10.115:8.5.pli: Yathā vo bhagavā byākareyya tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
an10.115:8.5.eng: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

an10.115:9.1.pli: “Addhāvuso ānanda, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti passaṃ passati cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato.
an10.115:9.1.eng: “Certainly he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

an10.115:9.2.pli: So ceva panetassa kālo ahosi yaṃ mayaṃ bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma,
an10.115:9.2.eng: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.

an10.115:9.3.pli: yathā no bhagavā byākareyya tathā naṃ dhāreyyāma.
an10.115:9.3.eng: We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.

an10.115:9.4.pli: Api cāyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an10.115:9.4.eng: Still, Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.

an10.115:9.5.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.
an10.115:9.5.eng: You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief summary recital given by the Buddha.

an10.115:9.6.eng: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”

an10.115:10.1.eng: “Then listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.115:10.2.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

an10.115:11.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
an10.115:11.1.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

an10.115:11.2.eng: ‘You should know bad principles and good principles.

an10.115:11.3.eng: And you should know bad results and good results.

an10.115:11.4.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti.
an10.115:11.4.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.’

an10.115:12.1.pli: Katamo cāvuso, adhammo, katamo ca dhammo, katamo ca anattho, katamo ca attho?
an10.115:12.1.eng: So what are bad principles? What are good principles? What are bad results? And what are good results?

an10.115:13.1.eng: Wrong view is a bad principle.

an10.115:13.2.eng: Right view is a good principle.

an10.115:13.3.pli: ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
an10.115:13.3.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong view are bad results.

an10.115:13.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
an10.115:13.4.eng: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right view are good results.

an10.115:14.1.eng: Wrong thought is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.2.eng: Right thought is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.3.eng: Wrong speech is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.4.eng: Right speech is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.5.eng: Wrong action is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.6.eng: Right action is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.7.eng: Wrong livelihood is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.8.eng: Right livelihood is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.9.eng: Wrong effort is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.10.eng: Right effort is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.11.eng: Wrong mindfulness is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.12.eng: Right mindfulness is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.13.eng: Wrong immersion is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.14.eng: Right immersion is a good principle. …

an10.115:14.15.eng: Wrong knowledge is a bad principle.

an10.115:14.16.eng: Right knowledge is a good principle. …

an10.115:15.1.eng: Wrong freedom is a bad principle.

an10.115:15.2.eng: Right freedom is a good principle.

an10.115:15.3.pli: ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
an10.115:15.3.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong freedom are bad results.

an10.115:15.4.pli: sammāvimuttipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
an10.115:15.4.eng: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right freedom are good results.

an10.115:16.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:
an10.115:16.1.eng: The Buddha gave this brief summary recital, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:

an10.115:16.2.eng: ‘You should know bad principles and good principles …

an10.115:16.3.pli: tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti, imassa kho ahaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
an10.115:16.3.eng: and practice accordingly.’ And this is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary recital.

an10.115:16.4.pli: Ākaṅkhamānā ca pana tumhe, āvuso, bhagavantaṃyeva upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha.
an10.115:16.4.eng: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.

an10.115:16.5.pli: Yathā vo bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
an10.115:16.5.eng: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

an10.115:17.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an10.115:17.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” said those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Ānanda said. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then they said:

an10.115:18.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho no bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho:

an10.115:19.1.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato etadahosi:

an10.115:19.2.pli: ‘idaṃ kho no, āvuso, bhagavā saṅkhittena uddesaṃ uddisitvā vitthārena atthaṃ avibhajitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ paviṭṭho—

an10.115:19.5.pli: Ko nu kho imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajeyyā’ti?

an10.115:20.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ.

an10.115:20.3.pli: Pahoti cāyasmā ānando imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena uddesassa uddiṭṭhassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ vibhajituṃ.

an10.115:20.4.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyāma.

an10.115:20.5.pli: Yathā no āyasmā ānando byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā’ti.

an10.115:21.1.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamimhā; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etamatthaṃ apucchimhā.
an10.115:21.1.eng: “Sir, we went to Ānanda and asked him about this matter.

an10.115:21.2.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, āyasmatā ānandena imehi ākārehi imehi padehi imehi byañjanehi attho suvibhatto”ti.
an10.115:21.2.eng: And Ānanda clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”

an10.115:22.4.pli: Mañcepi tumhe, bhikkhave, upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipuccheyyātha, ahampi cetaṃ evamevaṃ byākareyyaṃ yathā taṃ ānandena byākataṃ.
an10.115:22.4.eng: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Ānanda.

an10.115:22.5.pli: Eso ceva tassa attho evañca naṃ dhāreyyāthā”ti.
an10.115:22.5.eng: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”

an10.116:1.1.pli: Atha kho ajito paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.116:1.1.eng: Then the wanderer Ajita went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an10.116:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ajito paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.116:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

an10.116:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, we have a spiritual companion called ‘Astute’.

an10.116:2.2.pli: Tena pañcamattāni cittaṭṭhānasatāni cintitāni, yehi aññatitthiyā upāraddhāva jānanti upāraddhasmā”ti.
an10.116:2.2.eng: He has worked out around five hundred arguments by which followers of other religions will know when they’ve been refuted.”

an10.116:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

an10.116:3.2.eng: “Mendicants, do you remember this Astute’s points?”

an10.116:3.3.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

an10.116:3.4.pli: yaṃ bhagavā bhāseyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an10.116:3.4.eng: Let the Buddha speak and the mendicants will remember it.”

an10.116:4.1.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.116:4.1.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.116:4.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an10.116:5.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena adhammikaṃ vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
an10.116:5.1.eng: “Mendicants, take a certain someone who rebuts and quashes unprincipled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

an10.116:5.2.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:

an10.116:5.3.eng: ‘He is truly astute! He is truly astute!’

an10.116:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena dhammikaṃ vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
an10.116:6.1.eng: Someone else rebuts and quashes principled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

an10.116:6.2.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:

an10.116:6.3.eng: ‘He is truly astute! He is truly astute!’

an10.116:7.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena dhammikañca vādaṃ adhammikañca vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
an10.116:7.1.eng: Someone else rebuts and quashes principled and unprincipled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

an10.116:7.2.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:

an10.116:7.3.eng: ‘He is truly astute! He is truly astute!’

an10.116:8.1.pli: Adhammo ca, bhikkhave, veditabbo dhammo ca;
an10.116:8.1.eng: Mendicants, you should know bad principles and good principles.

an10.116:8.2.eng: And you should know bad results and good results.

an10.116:8.3.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
an10.116:8.3.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.

an10.116:9.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, adhammo, katamo ca dhammo, katamo ca anattho, katamo ca attho?
an10.116:9.1.eng: So what are bad principles? What are good principles? What are bad results? And what are good results?

an10.116:9.2.eng: Wrong view is a bad principle.

an10.116:9.3.eng: Right view is a good principle.

an10.116:9.4.pli: ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
an10.116:9.4.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong view are bad results.

an10.116:9.5.pli: sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
an10.116:9.5.eng: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right view are good results.

an10.116:10.2.eng: Right thought is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.4.eng: Right speech is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.8.eng: Right livelihood is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.10.eng: Right effort is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.11.eng: Wrong mindfulness is a bad principle.

an10.116:10.12.eng: Right mindfulness is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.13.eng: Wrong immersion is a bad principle.

an10.116:10.14.eng: Right immersion is a good principle. …

an10.116:10.15.eng: Wrong knowledge is a bad principle.

an10.116:10.16.eng: Right knowledge is a good principle. …

an10.116:11.2.eng: Right freedom is a good principle.

an10.116:11.3.pli: ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
an10.116:11.3.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong freedom are bad results.

an10.116:11.4.pli: sammāvimuttipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
an10.116:11.4.eng: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right freedom are good results.

an10.116:12.1.eng: ‘You should know bad principles and good principles.

an10.116:12.2.eng: And you should know bad results and good results.

an10.116:12.3.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti,
an10.116:12.3.eng: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.’

an10.116:12.4.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an10.116:12.4.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an10.117:1.1.pli: Atha kho saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.117:1.1.eng: Then Saṅgārava the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an10.117:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.117:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an10.117:1.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, orimaṃ tīraṃ, kiṃ pārimaṃ tīran”ti?
an10.117:1.3.eng: “Worthy Gotama, what is the near shore? And what is the far shore?”

an10.117:1.4.pli: “Micchādiṭṭhi kho, brāhmaṇa, orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammādiṭṭhi pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.4.eng: “Wrong view is the near shore, brahmin, and right view is the far shore.

an10.117:1.5.pli: micchāsaṅkappo orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāsaṅkappo pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.5.eng: Wrong thought is the near shore, and right thought is the far shore.

an10.117:1.6.pli: micchāvācā orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāvācā pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.6.eng: Wrong speech is the near shore, and right speech is the far shore.

an10.117:1.7.pli: micchākammanto orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammākammanto pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.7.eng: Wrong action is the near shore, and right action is the far shore.

an10.117:1.8.pli: micchāājīvo orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāājīvo pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.8.eng: Wrong livelihood is the near shore, and right livelihood is the far shore.

an10.117:1.9.pli: micchāvāyāmo orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāvāyāmo pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.9.eng: Wrong effort is the near shore, and right effort is the far shore.

an10.117:1.10.pli: micchāsati orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāsati pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.10.eng: Wrong mindfulness is the near shore, and right mindfulness is the far shore.

an10.117:1.11.pli: micchāsamādhi orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāsamādhi pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.11.eng: Wrong immersion is the near shore, and right immersion is the far shore.

an10.117:1.12.pli: micchāñāṇaṃ orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāñāṇaṃ pārimaṃ tīraṃ;
an10.117:1.12.eng: Wrong knowledge is the near shore, and right knowledge is the far shore.

an10.117:1.13.pli: micchāvimutti orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāvimutti pārimaṃ tīranti.
an10.117:1.13.eng: Wrong freedom is the near shore, and right freedom is the far shore.

an10.117:1.14.pli: Idaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, orimaṃ tīraṃ, idaṃ pārimaṃ tīranti.
an10.117:1.14.eng: This is the near shore, and this is the far shore.

an10.117:2.2.eng: who cross to the far shore.

an10.117:3.1.eng: When the teaching is well explained,

an10.117:3.3.eng: are the ones who will cross over

an10.117:3.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.

an10.117:4.2.eng: an astute person should develop the bright.

an10.117:4.4.eng: for the seclusion so hard to enjoy,

an10.117:5.4.eng: would cleanse themselves of mental corruptions.

an10.117:6.1.eng: Those whose minds are rightly developed

an10.117:6.6.eng: they are quenched in this world.”

an10.118:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the near shore and the far shore.

an10.118:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an10.118:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an10.118:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an10.118:2.1.pli: “Katamañca, bhikkhave, orimaṃ tīraṃ, katamañca pārimaṃ tīraṃ?
an10.118:2.1.eng: “And what, mendicants, is the near shore? What is the far shore?

an10.118:2.2.pli: Micchādiṭṭhi orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammādiṭṭhi pārimaṃ tīraṃ …pe…
an10.118:2.2.eng: Wrong view is the near shore, and right view is the far shore. …

an10.118:2.3.pli: micchāvimutti orimaṃ tīraṃ, sammāvimutti pārimaṃ tīraṃ.
an10.118:2.3.eng: Wrong freedom is the near shore, and right freedom is the far shore.

an10.118:2.4.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, orimaṃ tīraṃ, idaṃ pārimaṃ tīranti.
an10.118:2.4.eng: This is the near shore, and this is the far shore.

an10.118:3.2.eng: who cross to the far shore.

an10.118:4.1.eng: When the teaching is well explained,

an10.118:4.3.eng: are the ones who will cross over

an10.118:4.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.

an10.118:5.2.eng: an astute person should develop the bright.

an10.118:5.4.eng: for the seclusion so hard to enjoy,

an10.118:6.3.eng: With no possessions, an astute person

an10.118:6.4.eng: should cleanse themselves of mental corruptions.

an10.118:7.1.eng: And those whose minds are rightly developed

an10.118:7.6.eng: they are quenched in this world.”
